name: Read and write numbers in standard form 1

skills.name: Recognise when a number is written in standard form
Write numbers greater than 1 in standard form
Write numbers between 0 and 1 in standard form
Convert standard form notation into non-standard form for numbers more than 1
Convert standard form notation into non-standard form for numbers between 0 and 1

explanations.A: I think you have chosen the number with the most digits, but as long as the digits represent a number that is greater or equal to 1 but less than 10, the length of the number doesn't matter.
explanations.B: It looks like you think the power must be positive. The power in standard form can be either positive or negative, as long as it is an integer.
explanations.C: It looks like you think the power has to be low. This is not the case. The power can have any positive or negative value, as long as it is an integer value.
explanations.D: Standard form is a useful way of writing very big or very small numbers. The conditions are that the number is written in two parts. The first part requires writing the digits in a way that the value is greater than or equal to 1 but less than 10. The second part requres writing × 10 to an integer power. Looking at the values in answer A–D, the value of the first part for answer D does not fit this rule because 0.7 < 1. Therefore, this is not in standard form.

explanations.B: This would be 0.00031, you have lost the zeros between the 3 and 1.
explanations.C: A number written in standard form is given in two parts, the first being just the digits in a way that the value is greater than or equal to 1 but less than 10, and the second part which is × 10 to a power. We have 3.001 as the first part, and then we would need to divide this by ten 4 times to give us 0.0003001, so the power is -4
explanations.D: It looks like you have counted the decimal places and written that number as your power. The digits should be written in a way that the value is greater than or equal to 1 but less than 10, the zeros between the 3 and 1 should be included in this. Then think about how many times you need to divide that by 10 to get the original number.
